title: Beth Lewis: The Art of Stability
content: Beth Lewis, a former professional dancer and movement specialist, discusses how she identifies problematic movement patterns and postures to help individuals relieve pain, avoid injury, and move better within all types of exercise. She explains how movement is a trainable skill and provides suggestions for what people can add to their exercise routine to benefit their health and longevity.

title: Beth’s “way of no way” training philosophy
content: Beth’s approach draws from a variety of disciplines including Functional Range Conditioning, Postural Restoration Institute, and Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization.

title: Beth’s background in dancing and how she ended up in New York City
content: Beth earned a degree in dance performance and danced professionally for four years with a dance company named Pilobolus. This dance company is known for creating an athletic style of dance referred to as weight shifting.

title: Beth’s transition to fitness coaching and how her training philosophy has evolved
content: Beth transitioned to fitness coaching and her training philosophy has evolved over time.

title: Beth's Training Modes
content: Beth split her time training clients between a few modes: Private 1 on 1 in general strength and conditioning, Group classes, and teaching classes at CITYROW.

title: Beth's Evolution in Philosophy on Exercise Training
content: Beth’s initial philosophy was rooted in traditional strength and conditioning with particular emphasis on “do no harm”. She started to learn more about Olympic lifting and powerlifting at a new gym called Soho Strength Lab. This led her to Functional Range Conditioning (FRC), which made a big difference in helping her help her clients move better.

title: Functional Range Conditioning and Scapular Mobility
content: Functional Range Conditioning (FRC) is primarily focused on getting to end range of motion and reinforcing that range by challenging it. Controlled articular rotations (CARs) are a component of FRC that involve moving a joint through the biggest circle possible without any extraneous or compensatory movement. Progressive and regressive angular isometric loading (PAILs and RAILs, respectively) is the application of isometric load to an end range of motion. Despite the focus on movement and mobility, Beth considers FRC as more of a performance than a rehab modality.

title: An Overview of Postural Restoration Institute, and Peter’s Squat Assessment
content: The Postural Restoration Institute (PRI) is more oriented towards clinicians and is focused on patterns throughout the body. Peter and Beth first met in January 2019. Then, Beth has Peter do a squat assessment and observed the following: Standing on his right side, A dent right above his iliac crest from the compression on the right side, A left scapular hike, And he was spinning out slightly to the left.

title: The Important Connection Between the Ribs and Breathing
content: The ribs are your center of mass, and respiration is one of our constant stresses. The ribs have important relevance to breathing – if they do not externally rotate during exhalation, inhalation will be altered and it can lead to anterior tilt, rib flare, scapular retraction, or forward head posture. Ultimately, this can lead to plantar fasciitis, pain in a variety of places, or even anxiety.

title: The Role of Sitting and External Stress in Chronic Muscular Tension
content: Another constant stress is gravity — How are you working with or against gravity? If you’re not breathing well, if you’re not dealing with gravity well, that has a high cost.

title: Sitting too much
content: Sitting a lot is not good, but it’s more about the sitting in the same position. Taking breaks and changing sitting position is important. It’s never good to be in the same position all the time.

title: Chronic stress (as opposed to acute distress)
content: External stress has a big impact on body tension. Causes you to not sleep well. Even staring at a screen—Your eyes are always fixed on the screen so you’re missing out a lot of the peripheral parts of vision, which is stressful because you don’t know what’s going on around you. We have more chronic stress than our ancestors (who mostly experienced acute stress).

title: Importance of maintaining use of your toes, minimalist footwear, and toe yoga
content: Going from a minimalist foot pattern to a heavily supported shoe has altered our attachment to the ground. Modern footwear decreases one’s ability to use their toes. Beth has her clients do “toe yoga” to help regain and maintain capacity to use the toes. The ability to use your toes is important because they dampen force. Modern shoes often squeeze your toes and minimize the use of your toes therefore your body becomes accustomed to not needing them.

title: Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization (DNS)
content: Dynamic Neuromuscular Stabilization (DNS) is based on a re-engineering of the development of movement patterns that occurs between three months of age and walking. The idea of that we are born with the innate ability to move efficiently, but by the time kids are school age (6) they are sitting all day and starting to lose the natural movement patterns. It was originally developed to help kids with cerebral palsy, but is now used to help anyone with movement deficiencies.

title: A different view on knee valgus
content: Completely avoiding knee valgus is not realistic or appropriate. When exercising with heavy weights (i.e., 65% of capacity or more), more care should be taken to execute the best movement possible, including avoidance of knee valgus.

title: Conscious versus subconscious movement
content: Movement in everyday life should be as subconscious as possible. A lot of people that are in pain or discomfort or worried about hurting themselves have this really big bracing strategy in their trunk. A person needs to instead be reactive and adaptive to be able to respond to different changes in their environment. Being too fixated on making things conscious leads to being less adaptive.

title: Posture and Movement
content: Beth does not believe in there being a such thing as bad posture. She believes that moving around and never maintaining a single posture for too long is more important than superiority of any one particular posture. Counteracting sitting by getting up and moving often. When Beth is working with someone for the first time, she addresses what she sees. For example, if someone is standing a particular way as their response to gravity, then she’d give them a different option — not because it’s “bad” but it could be causing them discomfort — and a different option could get them out of discomfort and make them more adaptable.

title: Assessment and Treatment
content: Beth assessment and treatment of Peter. Peter came to Beth with SI joint pain. Beth noticed he had less stretchability or mobility on the right side of your rib cage. Beth did a lot of breathing work with Peter because he was also presenting with a pretty significant bilateral rib flare. Beth calls the rib flaring Peter’s “strategy” for moving through life (basic walking, deadlift, etc.). Peter’s QLs (big muscles in the lower part of your back) were locked and loaded 24/7 which explains the rib flaring, anterior tilt of the pelvis. This is not uncommon—Many people have restrictions that are preventing them from moving well, including locked quadratus lumborum muscles, rib flare, and anterior pelvic tilt. It can require a lot of time and practice to reverse such restrictions, which can make it difficult to get buy in for the process. The process is not as fun as bootcamp-style “crushing it” workouts, which also contributes to difficulty with buy in. Plus, exercising like this with restrictions can either make it more difficult to reverse any present restrictions or even make them worse. How does Beth keep clients motivated to keep going? First, she educates them the best she can, “I am very real.” Pointing out progress. She constantly points out the little improvements, taking progress photos, etc. Reminding clients of wins, such as Peter’s alleviation of sacroiliac joint pain, helps.

title: Lifting Weights and Deadlifts
content: Beth’s appreciation for lifting weights. She’s a “meathead at heart”. She particularly loves to deadlift (trap bar and straight bar).

title: Split Leg Exercises
content: Beth emphasizes split leg exercises because of their applicability to hip stability and their greater potential for exposing movement limitations. Examples include split squats, walking lunges, single leg Romanian deadlift, etc.

title: Dancing (and moving well) into old age
content: Dancing requires a level of coordination and balance that goes beyond most other activities. It is possible to improve balance through training. Beth has clients move with their eyes closed to improve their balance. Balance declines with age and it’s better to address deficiencies sooner rather than later. Beth has an 80-year old client who came to her unable to get up and down off of the floor without assistance – now he can do so on his own, and only using one hand for support.

title: The importance of the hamstrings versus abs
content: Beth emphasizes the importance of the hamstrings more so than the abdominals for assisting posterior pelvic tilt. She has her clients do bicep curls in a kneeling position to help facilitate activation of the hamstrings. Another reason why using the abdominals for posterior pelvic tilt is less desirable is because it limits exhalation. When Peter first started working with Beth, he relied more on his quadriceps to deadlift because of his difficulty activating his hamstrings.

title: Benefits of rowing, and why everyone should add it to their exercise regimen
content: Beth thinks every human should row. Rowing promotes backward movement and scapular mobility. Beth has used rowing to help resolve back pain in a lot of her clients. The starting position of rowing is similar to the start of a deadlift, where the posterior chain muscles are pre-loaded. The entire drive portion of rowing is actually similar to the concentric phase of a deadlift. One of the hardest parts of rowing well is learning to lessen tension while pulling in the bar and relaxing during the return to the starting position. Rowing is 60% legs, 30% hips, and only 10% gripping and pulling the bar.

title: Benefits of Eccentric Strength
content: An example of eccentric versus concentric strength that is extremely relevant to sports is accelerating and decelerating, respectively. Beth equates lack of eccentric strength to a sports car without brakes. Eccentric strength also promotes control, such as in the descent phase of a squat or lunge.

title: Flexibility and HIIT
content: Beth considers flexibility to be relative to the range of motion that can be controlled. She thinks that HIIT should be done about 20% of the time, although she also acknowledges that most people need more Zone 2 exercise. In regard to clients who want to “crush it all the time,” Beth tells them “you should rarely feel like death. It’s just not what it’s about.”

title: Training versus Playing Sports
content: Beth believes that sports should not be used as a replacement for exercise. She thinks that kids should spend more time playing and less time at desks and on screens. Kids who spend time playing and are involved with sports will have a better foundation of movement and will learn movement changes more easily. However, sport specialization and repetitive sports can hurt rather than help movement capacity.

title: PAILs and RAILs
content: PAILs and RAILs should be done at the end of a workout because they are neurologically challenging. Prior to starting a pail or rail, a stretch should be held for about two minutes. PAILs are performed by isometrically contracting the stretched muscles, while still stretched. RAILs are performed by isometrically contracting the muscles opposing the stretched muscles, as if creating additional stretch. One to two rounds for a particular stretch is adequate.

title: Hamstring Control
content: The purpose of the exercise is to learn how to activate the hamstrings with minimal activation of the abdominals. If done properly, breathing should feel normal and not restrained. The exercise is initiated with posterior pelvic tilt. Similar to PAILs and RAILs, the intensity of isometric contraction should be progressively increased. Finally, the hips should be lifted about an inch off the floor to further increase the load.

title: Deadlift
content: Prior to initiating the lift, a “wedge” is developed, which is basically a pre-loading of the appropriate muscles. It is important that the hips move back to maintain emphasis on the appropriate muscles. Peter primarily deadlifts with a hex bar, but periodically uses a straight bar (with lighter load) to reinforce emphasis on the hamstrings. The isometric dumbbell deadlift can be used to train the “wedge,” or to maintain strength when access to equipment is limited (i.e., during travel).

title: Eccentric-Focused Step-Up
content: Mimics the gait pattern. This exercise is just as much about positioning and posture (particularly the ribs) as it is about leg strengthening.

title: Breathing Assessment
content: Should feel ribs expanding and retracting. Reaching the arms up and protracting the scapulae helps promote proper rib positioning.

title: Assessments
content: Toe touch.

title: Late Stance Phase
content: Tests the reflexivity of the lower leg. Doubles as both an assessment and training. 80-85% of weight is on front leg. Eyes are closed. Head is rotated right and left for vestibular challenge. Hugging a ball is helpful when back muscles are used excessively. This helps to establish more of a posterior pelvic tilt, which helps to relax the back muscles.

title: Segmental Cat Cow and CARs
content: Segmental Cat Cow doubles as both an assessment and training for spinal segmentation. Segmental movement implies movement being spread across multiple vertebrae rather than movement being isolated to one area. Scapular CARs is similar to segmental cat cow, this doubles as an assessment and training. Movement should be isolated to the shoulder blades – arms should not move far from sides. Can also be done with arms forward instead of at sides to accentuate protraction and retraction.

title: Tricep Extensions and Eccentric Split Squat
content: Tricep Extensions is an example of FRC and applying challenge at end range of motion. Not a lot of weight is needed – Peter uses only 5-7 lbs. Eccentric Split Squat spinal muscles should be unloaded to ensure that control is primarily coming from legs. Descent should be paced at a count of 5, Ascent at a count of 1. Knee should only lightly touch the floor. Main emphasis is on the control of the descent and bottom position. Restrained breathing and elevation of the shoulders during the ascent are indications of a lack of control.

title: Rowing
content: Heels can be moderately elevated at the catch position, but with good sense of toes and forefoot. The catch position is similar to the deadlift wedge. Hips should open while pushing back from the catch position. Pull of the bar at the end of the motion should feel easy. During recovery, should feel a sense of being pulled in by the bar. Practicing without the toe straps helps to reinforce proper mechanics. Rowing can also be done single leg, which is particularly valuable for people with a leg injury.

title: Supporting drills
content: Isometrically loading the catch position can be helpful for learning to develop the appropriate amount of tension. Isolating and focusing on the leg movement portion helps to reinforce proper synchronization of knee and hip movement (they should open at the same time). Doing “half slides” (minus the full catch) helps to reinforce proper timing of tensing and relaxing the core.

title: Pace and Protocol
content: Should start at lower speeds (strokes per minute). Since there is considerable cognitive skill involved with rowing technique, slower speeds facilitate reinforcement of proper technique. Pace can gradually be increased as technique becomes grooved. Beth recommends doing 1-1.5 minutes at a time with 30-45 second breaks to allow for a cognitive reset. This can be repeated many times to make it into a cardiovascular workout. Speed can be slowly increased as these cycles are repeated.
